Idiom (Niuean): Fano hifo e la, fano foki e manava
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To endure difficulties with hope; to persevere despite hardship
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Kia fakauka he gahua mo e tau mena uka
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Old seafaring proverb referring to perseverance despite sunset darkness
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Niuean): /ˈfa.no ˈhi.fo e ˈla, ˈfa.no ˈfo.ki e maˈna.va/
First Example Sentence: Kua fakamanatu e matua haaku: ‘Fano hifo e la, fano foki e manava.’
Second Example Sentence: He taimi uka, ne manatu au ke he kupu ia, ti fakauka.
Third Example Sentence: Ko e la ne hifo, ka e nakai hifo e manava he tagata loto toa.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed nominal clause with parallel structure
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Ko e tagata nakai fakamaama e manatu, nakai aoga e gahua
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional Niuean proverb on decisiveness and determination
First Example Sentence: Ko e tagata ua, gahua mole — kua fakamaama e matua ke ako ai e fanau.
Second Example Sentence: Ne tutala e pule: ‘Ko e tagata ua, gahua mole.’
Third Example Sentence: He magafaoa, ne fakakite e tau tagata poto e kupu ia ke fakafeleveia e tau fifine.

Second Example Sentence: He magaaho lotomafiti, ne nakai maeke ke nofo au — loto taufetuli mo e matagi.
Third Example Sentence: Ne fai kupu e matua: ‘Taofi e loto, nakai galo mo e matagi.’

First Example Sentence: Nakai fai mena ke kai e tau kupu — ko e fakakata fua.

Second Example Sentence: He magafaoa fakamahani, kua moua e hau he tau.
Third Example Sentence: Ko e kupu ia e fakafifitaki he tau matutaki Niue.

Idiom (Niuean): Tala pē e aho, ti hemanatu
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause with sequential verb phrase
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To gossip or reveal secrets carelessly
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Ko e tagata ne talahau e mena kua lata ke hūhū
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to local humor about talkative elders or gossipers

Second Example Sentence: Ko e tagata nei, tala pē e aho, nakai manatu ke he mena aoga.
Third Example Sentence: Ne fakakata e tau tagata ke he kupu ia: tala pē e aho, ti hemanatu.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Drawn from traditional ocean fishing imagery; unpredictability of fish
First Example Sentence: Ko e tagata nei, tuga e ika he tahi — nakai maeke ke hopo.
Second Example Sentence: He tau feleveiaaga, kua fai tagata tuga e ika he tahi.
Third Example Sentence: Fakaalofa e falu tagata he tagata tuga e ika he tahi.

Second Example Sentence: He aho fakamatai, ne talahau e kupu ia ke he fanau.
Third Example Sentence: Kua manatu au he kupu: to kai e mena ne moua — ke ako ai.
